turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: What is this? What's going on, who is that?

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: It's the receptionist at one of the places I service video equipment -- she's very pretty and, you know, she never even talks to me and then today I come in and she's all "I saw you on TV the other night... You were so great ... " Next thing I know we're ...

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Next thing you know! Why didn't you stop?

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: Stop? I'm a guy. I don't stop. The woman's supposed to stop. We're the gas, they're the brakes.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I don't even know her. All I know is she likes Snapple.

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: No, not her. Shari. Go over there and talk to her

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Why me?

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: You brought the cameras here!

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: You brought the girl!

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: Please!

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: If I go over to Shari, the camera's going there, too.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: ... Ray?

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Oh, man, I've been trying to call you.

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Look, we gotta talk.

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: Save it.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: What are we gonna fight? Ray, please, listen to me --

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: Cassie...

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: Good-bye, brother!

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Ray, come an--

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: Cliff left her, thanks to you.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Me?!

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: That's right. You put Cliff on television. So then he decided he was too good for her and he left.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I put his -- who --  Look, Marsh, he's not that good a singer, he'll be back.

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: Come on, Ma.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Let's remember how I got into this. "Please, Eddie, do this for me. I can't get a break."

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: You know what your problem is?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Yeah. My problem is I've got a brother who writes a sentence like "We grew up in a small, little bedroom." As opposed to a big, little bedroom?

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: I got paid by the word! No! Your problem is you don't ever want anything to be your fault.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Me?! That's you!

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: I commit. I take a chance. You wanted to be the guy on TV, but you didn't want to say you wanted to. So you have me talk you into it so you get what you want, but if it goes bad it's not your fault.

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: And each contestant gets one of these.  An "I tried to screw a network executive" tee-shirt.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: A hundred per cent cotton. Okay, here we go, Andy.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Ray, where do you keep the glasses?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Oh, is Shari here? Why didn't you just say so? Why are you giving me a song-and-dance about being tired?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Hi, Shari.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Who's Shari?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Who's --

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Mr. Pekurny. I'm sorry to bother you. My son would just love to have your autograph.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: No problema.  You want a picture?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: No -- keep it.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: I love you! 1 want to marry you!

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: You don't recognize me.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: No. Am I supposed to?

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: Who is it?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: It's Ed.

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: Quite a shithole, isn't it?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: It could be, if you fixed it up. How did you... ? I mean how does anyone ... wind up like this?

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: I was in jail.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: The whole time? Eighteen years?

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: No. Two times.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: What...

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: Check forging.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Oh, man! So...

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: The last two years, I've been a limousine driver, but I don't see well anymore, so...

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: So you saw me on TV and you said "Hey, let me jump on this."

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: I need help. How many times if just one little thing that I needed would've happened, it would've changed everything. If I had a few dollars when an opportunity came along or... the tumblers just never clicked for me.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: All right... This is my father, I don't know what the hell he can do, but if anyone out there can help him -- get him a job - I'11 ... help you. I'11 ... mention your business or ... I don't know, we'11 figure it out.  I gotta go.

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: Ed... I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Yeah? That's good. Sorry is good. You know I finished that model.

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: What...

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: The pirate ship.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: -- That we were doing "together." I finished it. It came out great! Because no one was standing over my shoulder bothering me - "That's too much glue. You're using too much glue."

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: Do you still have it?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: No. Ray sat on it. I'11 see you.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: That girl's an idiot.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: What?... Why?

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: I'm Jill. I really like your show. I think you're great.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Thanks... That's ...

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Oh, yeah, I love those. Yeah... those are funny...

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Well, it was really nice meeting you and, uh...  I'd better get a cab.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Um... They gave me a limo, uh...

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Oh, great! Thanks. I'm just going uptown.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Oh!!

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: We have to stop meeting like this.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Hm?

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Are you busy tomorrow night?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Why don't you come over. And I'11 make dinner. And you bring a movie. And ... We'11 make a night of it ... okay?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Can I help with anything?

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: No. It's going to be about a half-hour.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: What is? Oh, dinner!

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Mm.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Good?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Mm.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Ohhh...

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Ed?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Ohh... do you own a cat?

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Yeah. Why?

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: Look, can we all just sign the releases so we can get on with this?

turns.speaker: MARCIA
turns.text: What happened? You described this "crazy-kooky" family who'd be a million laughs on TV?

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: We don't have foibles.

turns.speaker: MARCIA
turns.text: Everyone has foibles. Then the whole country sees them on TV and mocks them. Then we have... mocked foibles.

turns.speaker: MARCIA
turns.text: Look, my life is not so great, that I want it shown on television. And neither is yours.

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: That's the point -- this could change things.

turns.speaker: MARCIA
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: For instance... me and my friend Bucky are buying out my boss. His equipment, trucks, client list, the whole shmear.

turns.speaker: MARCIA
turns.text: What does that have to do with... ?

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: If they keep Ed on for one full month, he gets a balloon payment.

turns.speaker: SHARI
turns.text: Sign here, please.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: That Ray was a pig. Ed is doll. You latch on to him honey.

turns.speaker: SHARI
turns.text: By the X.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Some more make-up wouldn't do you any harm. On TV you look a little washed out.

turns.speaker: SHARI
turns.text: What would I actually have to do to get you to sign this?

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Oh, an TV a minute and already an attitude.

turns.speaker: SHARI
turns.text: By the X. That's were two lines cross -- forming an X.

turns.speaker: MS. HOY
turns.text: Yo --

turns.speaker: CLASS
turns.text: pierdo.

turns.speaker: MS. HOY
turns.text: Tu

turns.text: pierdes.

turns.text: El/ella -

turns.speaker: CLASS

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: A few months before the election, she'd had an affair with my best friend Dave Novotny.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Don't tell me that.  I don't want to know that.

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: She's incredible.  Everything just gets soaked.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You could tell Dave was one of those guys who taught because they never wanted to leave high school in the first place, and that could get a little irritating sometimes, but basically he was a real good guy.

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: Foxy. . . Foxy. . . You know you're a cute little heartbreaker... Foxy... You know you're a sweet little love maker...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You did it at your house?  Your own house?

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: Look, Jim...  Okay.  I know it all seems crazy, and maybe it did start out, you know, for the... for the sex and the danger.  But now it's different.  Jim, what I'm trying to tell you is that Tracy and I are totally, totally in love.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: In love?

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: Yeah, it's serious.  I mean she inspires me in ways Sherry never has. She even wants to read my novel.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: But you haven't written your novel.

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: That's the whole point. It's all in my head; it's right here.  I just got to get it out there. Tracy wants me to write it so she can read it.  It's beautiful.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Dave, I'm just saying this as your friend.  What you're doing is really, really wrong, and you've got to stop.

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: You're not just jealous, are you?  I mean, we both used to talk about her

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: That was just talk!  Fantasy talk! What are you, nuts?  We talk about girls all the time, but it doesn't mean anything. I would never. . . I mean, I take very seriously our strict moral code.  The line you've crossed is... it's illegal and it's immoral.

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: I don't need a lecture on ethics, Jim, okay?  I know what --

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I'm not talking about ethics.  I'm talking about morals.

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: Sherry   Sherry  Sheerrry. ...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: He ended up moving back to Milwaukee to live with his parents. I haven't heard from him in a long time. Poor guy. I warned him.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: One night he took us editors out to celebrate after a deadline. Eventually Dave and I were left alone and we got to talking - not like teacher and student, but like two adults.

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: You know, Tracy... I don't know how to say this, but...

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: what?

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: Well, I notice you don't seem to have any close friends at Millard. You seem to be kind of a loner.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: No, I'm not. I'm just really busy.

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: I know.  I know its not by choice.  I just mean, well, being the kind of person you are, it must be really difficult to find someone you can talk to.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: What do you mean? What kind of person am I?

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: What kind of person?

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: Tracy, I've been watching you for going on two years now, and I think you are one of the most talented, hard-working, sensitive, attractive, brilliant students -- no, human beings -- I have ever met.  I mean, you're the real thing.  Special.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: And I know sometimes people like you have to pay a price for their greatness, and that price is loneliness.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: It was the first time somebody ever saw the real me, the me that nobody else knows.

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: Here, get down.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Thank God for Diane.  She was my best friend, my source of love and strength. Oh sure, we'd had our share of bumpy times, but we'd always seen them through.  After nine years of marriage, we were closer than ever.  And the secret? Good communication.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Anything wrong?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Everything's fine.  Just, you know, school.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Around that time Diane and I were hanging out a lot at Sherry Novotny's house, giving her our love and support and helping her make it through a difficult time.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Jim, don't.  You're scaring him.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: He likes it.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: You gonna do it? You gonna do it?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Yeah, uh, just a minute

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Come on, doit. Doit. Fill me up. Come on, fill me up

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Yeah, just --

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Do it!

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: How'd it go?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Fine. You know. We just went to Crossroads.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: You guys have fun?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Yeah. No. I mean, you know.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Well, Sherry's great.  But she can be a little much sometimes.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Don't you smartass me!  Don't you dare smartass me!  You just shut your mouth I  Now your mother and I have had a long talk with Halt Hendricks  --- we just got off the phone with him at home. You know, he doesn't want you back at Millard.  He's fed up with you.  Fed up!  And I don't blame him!

turns.speaker: JO
turns.text: Dick... Dick,..

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JO
turns.text: Tammy,  now we've come to a decision. He just think it would be best --

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: You're going to Catholic school next year.  You're going to Sacred Heart. Maybe they'll straighten you out!

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Having a problem with your eye there?

turns.speaker: JO
turns.text: Dick.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: All right.  Well, sure nice to meet you.

turns.speaker: JO
turns.text: So nice

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: What?  Right.  So let's start counting.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: Well, I thought that... well, the way it always works is that SGA president does a count, then the SGA advisor, you know, for the two independent counts.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Fine.  So do your count.  Start with president, and I'll be right back.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: You have the key, Mr. McAllister.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I just want to get this over with, so we can have the assembly and go home. We don't have much time until eighth period.  I have other things going on, too, you know.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: Okay.  Yeah.  We know

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: All right.  I'll be back

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: What d'you got?

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: I'm not supposed to tell. Not until you've counted too. We're each supposed to make an independent count.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You're kidding, right?

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: I thought those were the rules, Mr. McAllister. If they've changed in any way --

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Larry, we're not electing the fucking Pope here. Just tell me who won.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: Mr. M.?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Huh.  Okay.  Well, I guess I'd better do my count.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Larry?

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I think we've got a problem.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Mostly Tammy fans

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: See, it doesn't add up. There are only 801 ballots but 803 people voted. Two votes are missing. Check the register.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: He's right. Two people must have pocketed their ballots. Usually it's more.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: But, they were there I counted 803 votes.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: It happens, Larry. People make mistakes.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: I didn't make a mistake. Every vote was there when you sac down

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Larry? We've got twenty-five minutes until the assembly, and we still have to do counts for VP, Treasurer and Secretary. Mr. Hendricks and I have both verified the numbers, and unless you can come up with the ballots you claim are missing -

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: But, Mr. M. -

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Good morning, Mr. McAllister.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Not wasting any time, are you, Tracy?

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: You know what they say about the early bird.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Yes, I do.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Well, good luck there, Tracy

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Thanks, Mr. M.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Okay.  But we're still missing something key here.  What are we missing?

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Tracy.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Ethics are...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Now at the end of her junior year, Tracy was poised to win the presidency of the student body.  And so far she was running unopposed.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: ...the rules of conduct determined by a culture at a...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Oh.  There's one more thing about Tracy I think you should know.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: I got all my signatures.  One hundred and fifty-eight -- way more than I need!

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Hey, that's super

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Here they are.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You can put those in my box.  I'll look at them tomorrow.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Could you approve them now?  I'd like to kick off my campaign right away, you know, in the morning.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Right

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Looks good to me.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Aren't you supposed to keep them?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: NO, that's fine

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: I thought you were supposed to keep them.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Okay, fine. Sure

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Thanks for everything.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You bet.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: I can't wait to start campaigning.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Should be easy.  So far no competition.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Hell, you know, Coca-Cola's the world's number one soft drink, but they spend more money than anybody on advertising. I guess that's how come they stay number one.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Yeah.  Okay.  well, good luck Tracy

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: You know, Mr. M., when I win the presidency, that means you and I are going to be spending a lot of time together next year.  And I for one would like that time to be harmonious and productive. Wouldn't you?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Sure

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Okay. That's good. I just wanted to make sure.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Good luck, Tracy.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Fuck me, Mr. McAllister

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: So like I was saying, things were going pretty well in my life.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: You're the advisor.  You should stop her.  She's not qualified.  She's just a sophomore.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Calm down, Tracy.  Just calm down.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Are you sure all her signatures are real?  It's not easy to get all those signatures.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: As far as I know, they--

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: These are a bunch of burn-outs. And look at this one, I can't even read this one.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Looks like Tim Kobza.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Tim Kobza?  Tim Kobza!  Who's he? I've never heard of him!

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Look, why don't we just forget about Tammy?  We'll have the assembly tomorrow, everybody'll make their speeches, and I'm sure everything will be fine.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I guess you know why you're here

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: If it's about the posters, I think it's so awful. It's a travesty.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: A travesty.  Huh.  That's interesting, because I think you did it.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Wait - are you accusing me? You're not serious.  I can't... Mr. McAllister, we have worked together on SGA for three solid years and... I mean, I can't believe it. I'm... I'm shocked!

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Mr. M., I am running on my qualifications.  I would never need to resort to, you know, to vandalism like a, you know... Plus, my own best banner was torn down.  Did I do that too?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Were you or were you not working in the Watchdog office over the weekend?

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: I was.  So?  Mr. Pecharda let me in. As you know, with all my responsibilities I often come in on the weekend and have permission to do so. But I left very early, around 6:30.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: 6:30.  How do you know what time the posters were torn down?

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: I don't.  I just know they were there when I left.  I'm giving you helpful information is all.  You know, instead of wasting time interrogating me, we should be out there trying to find out who did this.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Okay, Tracy, so who do you think did it?  Whom should we "interrogate?"

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: well, I don't know.  It could have been anybody.  There are a lot of, you know, subversive elements around Millard.  You know, like Rick Thieson and Kevin Speck and those burn-outs.  Or Doug Schenken - what about him?  Or what about Tammy Metzier?  Her whole thing is being anti- this and anti-that.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You're a very intelligent girl, Tracy. You have many admirable qualities.  But someday maybe you'll learn that being smart and always being on top and doing whatever you need to do to get ahead, and yes, stepping on people to get there, well, there's a lot more to life than that.  And in the end, you're only cheating yourself.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Why are you lecturing me?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: This isn't the time or the place to get into it, but there is, for just one example, a certain former colleague of mine, who made a very big mistake, a life mistake.  I think the lesson there is that, old and young, we ail make mistakes, and we have to learn that our actions, all of them, can carry serious consequences.  You're very young, Tracy underage, in fact -- but maybe one day you'll understand.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: I don't know what you're referring to, but I do know that if certain older and wiser people hadn't acted like such little babies and gotten all mushy, everything would be okay.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I agree.  But I also think certain young and naive people need to thank their lucky stars and be very, very grateful the whole school didn't find out about certain indiscretions which could have ruined their reputations, and chances to win certain elections.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: And I think certain older persons like you and your "colleague" shouldn't be leaching after their students, especially when some of them can't even get their own wives pregnant.  And they certainly shouldn't be running around making slanderous accusations. Especially when certain young, naive people's mothers are para-legal secretaries at the city's biggest law firm and have won many successful lawsuits. And if you want to keep questioning me like this, I won't continue without my attorney present.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Looks like today's your lucky day

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You're off the hook. Tammy here has confessed.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: I told you!  I told you!  You're going to pay for my banner!

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: That's enough, Tracy.  Quit while you're ahead, okay?  I'll handle this.  Could you ask Walt to come in?

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Act surprised. Walk slowly to the podium.  Be modest.  Thank them for this incredible honor.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: That said, the whole point of an election is to choose winners, and that you have done.  We'll begin with president.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Hello, Mr. M.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Hello, Tracy.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: So what brings you here?

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: I'm looking at new cars.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Oh.  New cars.  I see.  Well, you came to the right place

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: My mother's buying me a new car for college.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Huh.  Right.  College.  Wow.  Where are you going?  Where 'd you get into?

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Well, I got in everywhere I applied, but Cornell is my first choice.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Good for you.  Good for you

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: So, are you looking for something sporty or more practical?

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Sporty.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Where to?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Anywhere you want.  Just so long as we're not gone more than a half-hour.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Handles pretty good, don't you think?

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Plenty of pep, too.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: And this model comes with ABS and dual air bags standard.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: That sounds good.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: So Tracy?

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Why are you doing this?

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Doing what?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Coming to see me.  Are you trying to. . humiliate me?

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Nooo.  I just thought...  l mean, I am looking for a new car.  But I just thought, well, I'm going away soon, and you'll be stuck here and, I don't know, I just think maybe if things had been different we might have been, well, friends. Real friends.  And then things would be different.  Don't you think?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Well, I... I... that's very nice of you.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: I've got an idea.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: What's this?

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: My house.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: I want you to do something for me.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Swallows, unsure what heaven or hell awaits him.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: I just have to get something. I'll be right back.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Oh, is this...?  God. First one of these I haven't been in for a long time.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Would you sign it for me?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: What a surprise.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Take as much room as you want

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: I'm scared, Mr. M. I kind of don't feel ready for college.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You'll be fine.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: I hope so

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You will.

turns.speaker: WALT
turns.text: That little bitch made a fool of us I want her out of the election. Getting everybody all riled up like that.  She's finished, you hear me? Washed up.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Walt, we can't throw her out of the election just because we don't like her speech.  That's not what student government's about.

turns.speaker: WALT
turns.text: Yeah... whatever.  All I know is she's a troublemaker.  She's on my list.

turns.speaker: WALT
turns.text: Jim, where the hell have you been?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Nowhere.  I don't have class until second period.

turns.speaker: WALT
turns.text: Even tried you at home.  We've got a situation here.

turns.speaker: WALT
turns.text: Well, that speech she gave -- it was pretty, you know, pretty out there.  But we'll get to the bottom of it.  Don't you worry. Mr. McAllister is going to see to that.  Right, Jim?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Oh yeah, you bet.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Life would go on, and I would certainly be a stronger and wiser person from the experience.

turns.speaker: MISS BEEDER
turns.text: Uh, Jim?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Hmm?

turns.speaker: MISS BEEDER
turns.text: Walt needs to see you.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Oh.  Okay.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Walt will be speaking with you about this, but I need you to find someone to take over my classes. The lesson plans for the rest of the year are in my top right drawer.

turns.speaker: MISS BEEDER
turns.text: Okay, Jim. I understand.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Thanks. Well. I'm going home now.

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: You wanted to see me, Mr. M.?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Just wait outside. Tammy.

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: Okay.  But is this about the posters?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Possibly.  Please just wait outside.

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: Okay.  Because I know who did it.  So.. I'll just be outside.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: So... what do you have to tell me?

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: Well, this is hard for me, but I think it's important to be honest. Don't you?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: What is it. Tammy?

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: I'm the one.  I did it.  I tore down Paul's posters.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Looks at her skeptically  doesn't say a word.

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: I did it.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: And when did you do it?

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: This weekend.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Exactly when?

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: I don't know. Yesterday.  Sunday.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: And how did you get in the school?

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: Door was open.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Which door?

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: I don't know. All I know is I did it I

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I don't believe you.

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: I have proof.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: After Dave got fired, Sherry kicked him out of the house and filed for divorce.

turns.speaker: SHERRY
turns.text: Your novel? Are you fucking kidding me?

turns.speaker: SHERRY
turns.text: Could you get this? I can't

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Without Dave around. Sherry needed a lot of help around the house.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Here?

turns.speaker: SHERRY
turns.text: More this way.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Okay.  Give me the drill.

turns.speaker: SHERRY
turns.text: I can't afford this stuff right now.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Oh, come on.  You've had a hard year, you're cooped up with the kid all the time.  Let go; live a little.

turns.speaker: SHERRY
turns.text: You sure?
